  • Program Control

The top level, which decides what is to be done and then carries this plan out.

  • §2. Main itself

§1. 

    define INTOOL_NAME "inform7"
    define INFORM7_BUILD "inform7 [[Build Number]]"
    define HUMAN_READABLE_INTOOL_NAME "Inform 7"

§2. Main itself. On some platforms the core Inform compiler is a separate command-line tool, but on others it's compiled into the body of an application. So: 

    #ifndef SUPPRESS_MAIN
    int main(int argc, char *argv[]) {
        return Main::core_inform_main(argc, argv);
    }
    #endif

The function main is used in 2/pt (§52), 2/pl2 (§3.1), 2/pck (§2), 3/rst (§6), 4/am (§26.1), 8/ef (§26), 8/ed2 (§3.2), 10/varc (§14), 19/tb (§27, §27.1, §27.1.3, §29), 21/rl2 (§23), 26/uo (§11.1), 27/in (§8), 2/cc (§1), 2/lnk (§1), 2/res (§1), 3/cg (§1), 2/hf (§6).

§3. As a matter of policy, no module is allowed to start or stop the foundation module, not even the mighty core; so we take care of that with one more intermediary: 

    int Main::core_inform_main(int argc, char *argv[]) {
        Foundation::start();
        WordsModule::start();
        InflectionsModule::start();
        SyntaxModule::start();
        LinguisticsModule::start();
        KindsModule::start();
        ProblemsModule::start();
        CoreModule::start();
        IndexModule::start();
        InterModule::start();
        CodegenModule::start();

        int rv = CoreMain::main(argc, argv);

        WordsModule::end();
        InflectionsModule::end();
        SyntaxModule::end();
        LinguisticsModule::end();
        KindsModule::end();
        ProblemsModule::end();
        CoreModule::end();
        IndexModule::end();
        InterModule::end();
        CodegenModule::end();
        Foundation::end();
        return rv;
    }

The function Main::core_inform_main is used in §2.
